Sunny_Sweeney:
{{short description|American singer–songwriter}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2023}} {{Infobox person | name = Sunny Sweeney | image = NewCropSunnySweeney ByChristinaFeddersen HighRes4.jpg | caption = Sunny Sweeney promotional photo, 2016. | alt = | birth_name = Sunny Michaela Sweeney | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1976|12|07}} | birth_place = [[Longview, Texas]], U.S. | alma_mater = [[Texas State University]] | occupation = {{hlist|Singer–songwriter}} | years_active = 2005–present | spouse = 2 marriages, including
{{ubl|{{marriage|Jeff Helmer|2011|2018|reason=divorced}}}} | website = {{URL|sunnysweeney.com}} | children = | module = {{Infobox musical artist | embed = yes | genre = {{hlist|[[Americana (music)|Americana]]|[[Country music|country]]}} | instrument = {{hlist|Vocals|guitar}} | label = {{hlist|[[Big Machine Records|Big Machine]]|[[Republic Nashville]]|[[Thirty Tigers]]|Aunt Daddy}} }} }} '''Sunny Michaela Sweeney''' (born December 7, 1976){{cite book |title= Hot Country Songs: 1944-2012, Eighth edition|last=Whitburn |first=Joel |author-link=Joel Whitburn |year=2013 |publisher=Record Research |page=329}} is an American [[Country music|country]] singer–songwriter. Since beginning her career, her recordings have been released through five studio albums. Her best-selling album was 2011's ''[[Concrete (Sunny Sweeney album)|Concrete]]'', which spawned three charting country singles. Born and raised in Texas, Sweeney was exposed to music from an early age but did not pursue it professionally. Instead, she attempted an acting and comedy career. She then attended and graduated from [[Texas State University]] in 2001. It was after several jobs that Sweeney chose to pursue music professionally. After forming a band and gathering a regional following, her music was heard by [[Big Machine Records]]. The label would release her debut studio album titled ''[[Heartbreaker's Hall of Fame]]'' (2007). While its three singles failed to become success, it drew attention to Sweeney's career. She was then moved to [[Republic Nashville]], which released her second studio album ''Concrete''. Its lead single, "[[From a Table Away]]" reached the top ten of the American country songs chart in 2011. Sweeney's career shifted towards the [[Americana (music)|Americana]] genre with her next several releases. In addition, her recordings were issued on the independent [[Thirty Tigers]] and Aunt Daddy labels. Her 2014 album ''[[Provoked (Sunny Sweeney album)|Provoked]]'' reached the top 20 of the American country albums chart and received critical acclaim. It was followed by 2017's ''[[Trophy (Sunny Sweeney album)|Trophy]]'', which made both the American folk and independent albums charts. In 2023, her fifth studio album ''Married Alone'' was released. ==Early life== Sweeney was born in [[Longview, Texas]]. She was the only child born to parents Patrick and Sheila Sweeney.{{cite news |last1=Ward |first1=Angela |title=Longview native brings music home to The Levee |url=https://www.news-journal.com/features/longview-native-brings-music-home-to-the-levee/article_80d934f5-1a1f-5817-9187-1fdfad171bc5.html |access-date=9 April 2023 |work=[[Longview News-Journal]] |date=August 21, 2011}} Her biological parents later divorced and remarried new spouses. Sweeney would become close with both her new stepmother and stepfather.{{cite magazine |last1=Hight |first1=Jewly |title=Sunny Sweeney: You Had to Go and Prove Yourself |magazine=[[No Depression (magazine)|No Depression]] |date=November 28, 2014 |url=https://www.nodepression.com/sunny-sweeney-you-had-to-go-and-prove-yourself/ |access-date=9 April 2023}} Her grandfather, Art Sweeney, was a local musician who played clubs and events near her hometown. He was among her early exposures to music. While surrounded by music, Sunny herself did not perform publicly until singing [[Dolly Parton]]'s "[[9 to 5 (Dolly Parton song)|9 to 5]]" in her high school talent show. Upon graduating, Sweeney attempted other careers first instead of music.{{cite web |last1=Jurek |first1=Thom |title=Sunny Sweeney Biography |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/sunny-sweeney-mn0000939033/biography |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=9 April 2023}} Sweeney took several junior college courses before moving to [[New York City]] to attempt an acting career. After finding little success, she then moved to [[Austin, Texas]], where she joined an [[Improvisational theatre|improvisational comedy]] group. While she enjoyed being onstage she did not want to pursue comedy full time.{{cite magazine |last1=Skanse |first1=Richard |title=LSM Cover: Sunny Sweeney |magazine=Lone Star Music Magazine |date=July 1, 2011 |volume=4 |issue=4 |url=https://lonestarmusicmagazine.com/lsm-cover-sunny-sweeney/}}{{cite news |last1=Myers |first1=Frances |title=Sunny Sweeney performs during opening ceremonies of Iowa Games |url=https://iowastatedaily.com/133708/news/sunny-sweeney-performs-during-opening-ceremonies-of-iowa-games/ |access-date=9 April 2023 |work=[[Iowa State Daily]] |date=July 13, 2012}} Instead, she attended [[Texas State University]].{{cite news |last1=Baker |first1=Brian |title=Country Singer Sunny Sweeney Plays Northern Kentucky's Southgate House Revival This Weekend |url=https://www.citybeat.com/music/country-singersongwriter-sunny-sweeney-12215571 |access-date=9 April 2023 |work=[[Cincinnati CityBeat]] |date=January 9, 2020}} Commuting five days a week, Sweeney graduated in 2001 with a degree in [[Public Relations]]. She then married and worked various jobs. This included a brief stint at a newspaper and a child support agency. While interning for the Propaganda Media music company, Sweeney got opportunities to watch artists perform onstage. After seeing several artists perform onstage, Sweeney realized she could do the same thing. "This guy’s getting paid to do this? I could get paid to do that," she recalled to ''Lone Star'' magazine. ==Career== [[File:Sunny Sweeney.jpg|200px|thumb|left|Sunny Sweeney performing.]] After college, she started a band and played local bars in Austin and began to branch out and play around Texas. She put out her first album with the production help of Tommy Detamore in March 2006. After gaining a following on the club circuit in her native Texas, Sweeney signed to the independent [[Big Machine Records]] label.{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p841085/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Sunny Sweeney biography |access-date=2008-01-07 |last=Reges |first=Margaret |work=[[Allmusic]]}} She also toured throughout [[Europe]] in 2007. Her debut album, ''Heartbreaker's Hall of Fame'', was initially self-released in March 2006, and was reissued in March 2007 on Big Machine.{{cite web|url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/news/newsitem.asp?xid=281|title=Sunny Sweeney signs with Big Machine|date=2006-11-16|work=Country Standard Time|access-date=2009-01-03}}{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/sweeney__sunny/bio.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070212061142/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/sweeney__sunny/bio.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=February 12, 2007 |title=Sunny Sweeney biography |access-date=2008-01-07 |work=[[Country Music Television]]}}{{cite web |url=http://www.gactv.com/gac/nw_cma_close_up/article/0,,GAC_26068_5508650,00.html |title=New Artist Spotlight: Sunny Sweeney |access-date=2008-01-07 |work=[[Great American Country]] }}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In 2009, Sweeney was signed as the first artist to [[Republic Nashville]], a newly founded joint venture between Big Machine and [[Universal Republic Records]].{{cite web|url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/news/newsitem.asp?xid=2955|title=New Nashville label starts with Sunny Sweeney aboard|date=2009-06-05|work=[[Country Standard Time]]|access-date=2009-06-05}} Her first single for the label is "[[From a Table Away]]," which was released on June 28, 2010. It became her first chart single when it debuted at No. 58 on the U.S. ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Songs]] chart for the week of June 26, 2010. In March 2011, the song entered the Top 10 of the chart. Republic Nashville released Sweeney's second studio album, ''[[Concrete (Sunny Sweeney album)|Concrete]]'' on August 23, 2011.{{cite web|last=Shelburne|first=Craig|title=Summer Preview: 12 New Country Albums|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1665973/summer-preview-12-new-country-albums.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110620065526/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1665973/summer-preview-12-new-country-albums.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=June 20, 2011|publisher=[[Country Music Television|CMT]]|access-date=June 17, 2011}} The album was produced by [[Brett Beavers]] consists of ten tracks, including one co-written with [[Radney Foster]] and Jay Clementi.{{cite web|last=Stark|first=Phyllis|title=Sunny Sweeney: One To Watch In 2011|url=http://social.entertainment.msn.com/music/blogs/one-country-blogpost.aspx?post=75ce0d04-9f9d-4980-b456-51f8010df05a|publisher=[[MSN]]|access-date=9 January 2011|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714124914/http://social.entertainment.msn.com/music/blogs/one-country-blogpost.aspx?post=75ce0d04-9f9d-4980-b456-51f8010df05a|archive-date=14 July 2011}} "[[Staying's Worse Than Leaving]]" and "[[Drink Myself Single]]" were released as the album's second and third singles, respectively, and both were minor Top 40 hits on the Hot Country Songs chart. Sweeney and Big Machine parted ways in 2012. In 2013, Sweeney signed a recording contract with the Thirty Tigers record label.{{Cite news|url=http://www.soundslikenashville.com/news/sunny-sweeney-signs-with-new-label-thirty-tigers/|title=Sunny Sweeney Inks New Record Deal|date=2013-05-14|work=Sounds Like Nashville|access-date=2017-03-08|language=en-US}} Her debut label single entitled "Bad Girl Phase" was released in June 2014. Through the fan-sponsored [[PledgeMusic]] program, Sweeney issued her third studio record, ''[[Provoked (Sunny Sweeney album)|Provoked]]'', on August 5, 2014.{{cite news|author=Vickye|title=Sunny Sweeney "Bad Girl Phase" - Single Review|website=For the Country Record}} "My Bed," a duet with [[Will Hoge]], was released in early 2015 as the album's second single.{{Cite news|url=http://www.soundslikenashville.com/news/sunny-sweeney-releases-new-single-bed/|title=Sunny Sweeney Releases New Single, 'My Bed'|date=2015-02-02|work=Sounds Like Nashville|access-date=2017-03-08|language=en-US}} Dreamer: A Tribute to Kent Finlay, released in early 2016 on Austin-based Eight 30 Records, features Sweeney and Randy Rogers' duet "Between You and Me."{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/dreamer-a-tribute-to-kent-finlay-mw0002916063 |title=Various Artists: Dreamer: A Tribute to Kent Finlay |work=AllMusic }} Sweeney's fourth studio album, ''Trophy'', was released on March 10, 2017.{{Cite news|url=http://www.soundslikenashville.com/reviews/album-review-sunny-sweeneys-trophy/|title=Album Review: Sunny Sweeney's 'Trophy'|date=2017-03-07|work=Sounds Like Nashville|access-date=2017-03-08|language=en-US}} Sweeney released her first live album, ''Recorded Live At The Machine Shop Recording Studio'', on November 13, 2020. Sweeney's fifth studio album, ''Married Alone'', was released on September 23, 2022. It includes a duet with [[Vince Gill]] on the title track as well as vocals from [[Paul Cauthen]] on “A Song Can’t Fix Everything”. ==Personal life== Sweeney has married and divorced twice. According to Sweeney, her first marriage was "really quick" and when she was "really young". The pair later divorced, but her first spouse's name has not been reported.{{cite magazine |last1=Despres |first1=Tricia |title=Sunny Sweeney Blames the Road for the Demise of Her Second Marriage: 'You Can't Nurture Anything' |magazine=[[People (magazine)|People]] |date=December 13, 2022 |url=https://people.com/country/sunny-sweeney-blames-touring-for-demise-of-second-marriage-cant-nuture-anything/ |access-date=13 April 2023}} She married her second husband Jeff Helmer on November 11, 2011. The pair wed in an intimate ceremony in [[Las Vegas, Nevada]], with only a few friends and family invited. At the time, Helmer was a Sergeant with [[Austin, Texas]], police department. He was previously a Staff Sergeant in the [[United States Air Force]].{{cite web |last1=Conaway |first1=Alanna |title=Sunny Sweeney Weds in Las Vegas on 11/11/11 |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/sunny-sweeney-married/ |website=[[Taste of Country]] |date=November 14, 2011 |access-date=13 April 2023}} "He is so supportive and just wants me to be happy and succeed," Sweeney said of the marriage in 2011.{{cite web |last1=Duvall |first1=Erin |title=Sunny Sweeney's Marriage Built on Mutual Support |url=https://theboot.com/sunny-sweeney-husband-jeff-married/ |website=The Boot |date=March 23, 2012 |access-date=13 April 2023}} The couple repeatedly attempted to have a child together, resulting in one miscarriage. Sweeney spoke of the miscarriage in 2017, "It makes you feel broken. It seems like no one talks about it, unless they know the person they’re talking to has also been through it."{{cite web |last1=Dukes |first1=Billy |title=Sunny Sweeney Shares Brutally Honest Miscarriage Story, Song |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/sunny-sweeney-miscarriage-song/ |website=[[Taste of Country]] |date=June 20, 2017 |access-date=13 April 2023}} Helmer and Sweeney divorced in 2018, citing her touring schedule for the marriage's demise. The pair still remain friends. ==Discography== {{main|Sunny Sweeney discography}} ;Studio albums * ''[[Heartbreaker's Hall of Fame]]'' (2006) * ''[[Concrete (Sunny Sweeney album)|Concrete]]'' (2011) * ''[[Provoked (Sunny Sweeney album)|Provoked]]'' (2014) * ''[[Trophy (Sunny Sweeney album)|Trophy]]'' (2017) * ''Married Alone'' (2022){{cite journal |last1=Sweeney |first1=Sunny |title=''Married Alone'' (Disc Information) |journal=[[Thirty Tigers]] |date=September 23, 2022 |id=18719 (CD); 793888918818 (LP barcode)}} ==Awards and nominations== {{awards table}} !{{Abbr|Ref.|Reference}} |- | 2012 | [[Academy of Country Music Awards]] | New Female Vocalist of the Year | {{nom}} | align="center"| {{cite web |title=Search Winners: Sunny Sweeney |url=https://www.acmcountry.com/winners?awardTitle=sunny+sweeney&awardCategory=&awardYear=&actionButton=Submit |website=[[Academy of Country Music]] |access-date=13 April 2023}} |- | 2018 | Texas Country Music Association | Female Vocalist of the Year | {{nom}} | align="center"| {{cite web |title=2018 Texas Country Music Awards Past Press Releases Below |url=https://www.texascountrymusicassociation.org/2018awards |website=Texas Country Music Association |access-date=13 April 2023}} |- |} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Sunny Sweeney}} *[http://www.sunnysweeney.com/ Official Website] {{Sunny Sweeney}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sweeney, Sunny}} [[Category:1976 births]] [[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]] [[Category:21st-century American women singers]] [[Category:American women country singers]] [[Category:American country singer-songwriters]] [[Category:Big Machine Records artists]] [[Category:Country musicians from Texas]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Republic Records artists]] [[Category:Singer-songwriters from Texas]] [[Category:Texas State University alumni]] [[Category:Thirty Tigers artists]]
